case_name: Collector of Customs v. Walton Watch Company

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1056 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1056 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated May 12, 1967 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 218 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated May 12, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 218 of 1966.

facts.text: Respondent carried on business as dealer in watches named Walton Watch Company in Calcutta in 1963.

anchor.surface_text: In 1963, the respondent carried on business as a dealer in watches in the name and style of Walton Watch Company in Calcutta.

facts.text: Respondent had another business premises for Walton Watch Company in 1955, which was wound up and stock transferred to current business.

anchor.surface_text: In 1955, he also used to have another business premises where he carried on the same business in the name of Walton Watch Company. That business was wound up in that year and he had the stock-in-trade of that business transferred to his business carried on in the name of Walton Watch Company.

facts.text: On March 19, 1963, Rummaging staff under the appellant raided respondent's business premises and seized 218 watches of foreign make.

anchor.surface_text: On March 19, 1963, the Rummaging.staff under the appellant raided the respondents business premises and seized 218 watches, all of foreign Make,

facts.text: 87 of the seized watches were released immediately upon respondent producing vouchers.

anchor.surface_text: 87 of these watches, however, were released on the respondent then and there producing vouchers relating to them.

facts.text: 21 more watches released on September 18, 1963 and February 27, 1964 upon producing more vouchers.

anchor.surface_text: Later on, 21 more watches were released on September 18, 1963 and February 27, 1964 on more vouchers having been produced.

facts.text: Customs authorities claimed respondent unable to produce documentary evidence for the rest of the watches.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Customs authorities, however, was that he was number able to produce documentary evidence in respect of the rest of the watches, and therefore. Their release was number possible.

facts.text: On March 6, 1964, appellant served notice under s.124(a) to respondent to show cause why rest of watches should not be confiscated and penalty imposed.

anchor.surface_text: On March 6, 1964, the appellant served on the respondent a numberice under s. 124 a  to show cause why the rest of the said watches should number be companyfiscated and personal penalty should number be imposed upon him.

facts.text: Watches seized on March 19, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Since the watches in question were seized on March 19, 1963,

facts.text: Initial six months period under s.110(2) expired on September 19, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: the initial period of six months provided under the, second subsection of S. 110 expired on September 19, 1963 and the respondent became entitled to the return of the said watches

facts.text: First extension of four months granted by Collector on September 19, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: But the appellants case was that an extension for a further period of four months was applied for and was granted by the Collector on September 19, 1963 under his power under the said proviso

facts.text: First extended period expired on January 19, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: The extended period of four months expired on January 19, 1964

facts.text: Second extension application made on January 3, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: and a further extension of two months was applied for on January 3, 1964.

facts.text: Second extension of two months granted by Collector on February 20, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: But the Collector passed his order granting further extension on February 20, 1964, that is to say, about a month after the first extended period had expired.

facts.text: Both extension orders passed ex parte without opportunity of hearing to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, both the extension orders were passed ex parte and without any opportunity of being heard having been given to the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Calcutta High Court against the extension orders.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the two orders of extension passed in the manner aforesaid, the respondent moved the High Court of Calcutta under Art. 226 of the Constitution,

facts.text: Single Judge of Calcutta High Court rejected the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge, who heard the writ petition, rejected this companytention holding that the proviso empowered the Collector to grant as many extensions as the companypletion of the inquiry and the issuance of the numberice under s. 124 a  required

facts.text: Division Bench of Calcutta High Court reversed Single Judge and allowed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: On an appeal by the respondent, a Division Bench of that High Court took a companytrary view. ... For the reasons above stated the Division Bench reversed the judgment of the Single Judge and allowed the writ petition.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal under certificate from Calcutta High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, under a certificate, raises two questions.

facts.text: Division Bench held second extension invalid as passed after expiry of first extended period without hearing.

anchor.surface_text: It held that the watches having been seized on March 19, 1963, the period of six months expired on September 18, 1963, ... It also held that the words sufficient cause being shown used in the proviso meant that the Collector had to decide an application for extension judicially

facts.text: Supreme Court held power under proviso to s.110(2) requires judicial approach and opportunity of hearing.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the first question must be answered In favour of the respondent, and therefore, the Division Bench was right in holding that the power under the proviso was quasijudicial, or at any rate, one requiring a judicial approach.

facts.text: Supreme Court ordered restoration of watches to respondent due to invalid extensions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, companysequently, was justified in ordering restoration of the watches in question to the respondent.

facts.text: Show cause notice under s.124(a) issued after extensions.

anchor.surface_text: On March 6, 1964, the appellant served on the respondent a numberice under s. 124 a

facts.text: Collector granted extensions on ground of inquiries pending at Bombay and Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that certain inquiries at Bombay and Delhi yet remained to be made.

issues.text: the proviso to s. 110(2) envisaged only one extension

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the two orders of extension passed in the manner aforesaid, the respondent moved the High Court of Calcutta under Art. 226 of the Constitution, contending that the proviso to s. 110 2  envisaged only one extension,

issues.text: the period of the first extension having expired on January 19, 1964 and no further extension having been granted by that date, he became entitled to restoration of the said watches and the second order extending the period by two months more granted a month after the expiry of the first extended period would be of no avail to the Customs authorities

anchor.surface_text: The second contention urged by the respondent was that the period of the first extension having expired on January 19, 1964 and no further extension having been granted by that date, he became entitled to restoration-of the said watches and the second order extending the period by two months more granted a month after the expiry of the first extended period would be of no avail to the Customs authorities.

issues.text: the liability to return the goods seized under s. 110(1) on the expiry of the time prescribed under sub-s.(2) is not absolute as it is subject to the period being extended for a period not exceeding six months, that is to say, within the overall period of one year therefore, there is no question of any right being vested in the respondent on the expiry of the first six months or the extended period or such right being divested until one year from the date of seizure has expired

anchor.surface_text: counsel for appellant formulated the following two contentions only 1 that the liability to return the goods seized under s. 110 1 on the expiry of the time prescribed under sub-s. 2 is not absolute as it is subject to the period being extended for a period not exceeding six months, that is to say, within the over all period of one year that therefore, there is no question of any right being vested in the respondent on the expiry of the first six months or the extended period or such right being divested until one year from the date of seizure has expired

issues.text: the proviso to s. 110(2) does not contemplate any notice to the respondent as the considerations which would weigh with the Collector or which would be relevant for granting extension would be of such a nature that they could not be disclosed, such disclosure being against public interest that only two requirements are envisaged for the extension of time and they are (i) that a sufficient cause is shown, and (ii) that the extension is within one year

anchor.surface_text: and 2 that the proviso to s. 1 10 2 does not contemplate any notice to the respondent as the considerations which would weigh with the Collector or which would be relevant for granting extension would be of such a nature that they could not be disclosed. such disclosure being against public interest that only two requirements are envisaged for the extension of time and they are i that a sufficient cause is shown, and ii that the extension is within one year.

holdings.text: The first question must be answered in favour of the respondent, and therefore, the Division Bench was right in holding that the power under the proviso was quasi-judicial, or at any rate, one requiring a judicial approach.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished 'reason to believe' in s.110(1) from 'sufficient cause being shown' in proviso requiring inquiry on facts; applied precedents like De Verteuil v Knaggs and Kraipak v Union of India; affects civil right to restoration; rejects equation with subjective powers in Sampathu Chetty etc.

holdings.text: An opportunity of being heard ought to have been given to the respondent before orders for extension were made.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, an opportunity of being heard ought to have been given to the respondent before orders for extension were made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from quasi-judicial nature or judicial approach required; ex parte orders expose decision to one-sided facts; Division Bench reasoning affirmed.

holdings.text: Both the extension orders were invalid as passed ex parte without opportunity of hearing.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, consequently, was justified in ordering restoration of the watches in question to the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admitted ex parte (no hearing given); power requires hearing; both first and second orders bad for same reason; invalidates retention post-expiry.

holdings.text: The High Court was justified in ordering restoration of the watches in question to the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, consequently, was justified in ordering restoration of the watches in question to the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequence of invalid ex parte extensions; statutory right to restoration under s.110(2) accrues on expiry without valid extension.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, such satisfaction, as laid down in Narayanappa v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Bangalore 1 , is number absolutely subjective inasmuch as the reasons for his belief have to be relevant and number extraneous. It is clear that the legislature was number prepared to use the same language while giving power to the Collector to extend time and deliberately used the expression sufficient cause being shown.

precedents.case_name: Narayanappa v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Bangalore
precedents.cited_proposition: satisfaction is not absolutely subjective; reasons for belief must be relevant and not extraneous

anchor.surface_text: In Lakhampals case 2 this Court noticed a similar diffe- rence of language used in Tr. 30 1 b and 30-A 9 of the Defence of India Rules, 1962 which dealt with two different types of powers. Though it was a case dealing with preventive detention, what is important is that the decision primarily depended on the difference in language used in the two rules and the difference it made in the character of the two powers.

precedents.cited_proposition: difference in language used in provisions affects the character of the powers conferred

anchor.surface_text: A similar expression, though number exactly the same, also came to be companystrued by the House of Lords in De Verteuil v. Knaggs Anr. 3 , a case often referred to while determining the nature of power. The question which arose there was whether under S. 203 of the Trinidad Immigration Ordinance, No. 161, the government companyld pass an order transferring indentured labour from one employer to another without numberice to the companycerned employer against whom companyplaints as to treatment of the laborers were made.

precedents.cited_proposition: ordinarily implies some form of inquiry and duty to give fair opportunity to be heard to the affected party even in administrative actions
precedents.cited_holding: duty of giving to any person against whom the complaint is made a fair opportunity to make any relevant statement and to controvert any relevant statement brought forward to his prejudice

anchor.surface_text: In Kraipak v. Union of India 1 the power of a selection board to prepare a selection list from amongst the public servants for appointment in the senior and junior scales was held to be quasijudicial although the board had numberpower of appointment itself. In doing so, this Court observed that the dividing line between judicial and administrative functions was thin and gradually evaporating, and that the functions performed by those doing judicial function and administrative function, where the rights of citizens are affected to their prejudice, had the same object, namely, to do justice and deciding the question fairly and justly.

precedents.cited_proposition: powers affecting rights of citizens require fair and just decision, akin to quasi-judicial even if administrative

anchor.surface_text: The Court also pointed out that in recent years the companycept of quasi- judicial power has been undergoing a radical change and numbered with approval the decision in Regina v. Criminal Injuries Compensation Board Ex parta Lain 2 where it was held that certiorari would be available number only where, the impugned order infringes immediately enforceable rights but also where it is a paste as a result of which legally enforceable rights may be affected.

precedents.case_name: Regina v. Criminal Injuries Compensation Board Ex parte Lain
precedents.cited_proposition: certiorari available not only where rights immediately infringed but also where they may be affected

anchor.surface_text: If the power of preparing a selection list without the power to appoint, as in Kraipaks case , and power to transfer indentured labour from one to another employer, as in De Verteuil v. Knaggs 2 , are held, in the companytext of their respective provision I to be quasi-judicial powers, there is numberreason why, when the statute requires the determination of a sufficient cause on facts produced before the Collector should be held number to be a quasi judicial function or at least a function requiring judicial approach.

precedents.cited_proposition: preparing selection list is quasi-judicial power

anchor.surface_text: ...as in Kraipaks case , and power to transfer indentured labour from one to another employer, as in De Verteuil v. Knaggs 2 , are held, in the companytext of their respective provision I to be quasi-judicial powers...

precedents.cited_proposition: transferring indentured labour is quasi-judicial power requiring fair hearing

anchor.surface_text: In a recent decision in Sheikh Mohammed Sayeed v. Assistant Collector of Customs 3 a companytrary view has, however, been taken by a single Judge of the High Court of Calcutta. The extension order there was passed before the expiry of the initial six months period. But the companytention raised was that an opportunity to be heard should have been given to the petitioner.

precedents.case_name: Sheikh Mohammed Sayeed v. Assistant Collector of Customs
precedents.cited_proposition: no opportunity of hearing required for extension under proviso to s.110(2)

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge distinguished the decision of the Division Bench under this appeal reported in A.I.R. 1968 Cal. 28 on the ground that the question involved in that decision was whether an opportunity of being heard had to be given in respect only of an extension when the right to restoration of the goods in question has already accrued to the party from whom they were seized...

precedents.cited_proposition: extension power requires opportunity of hearing especially after right to restoration accrues

anchor.surface_text: As for his decision on the nature of the power,, the learned Judge relied on decisions in Collector of Customs v. N. Sampathu Chetty 1 , Babulal Amthalal v. Collector of Customs 2 , Pukhraj v. Kohli 3 and Nathmal Jalan v. Additional Collector of CUStOMS 4 which were all cases where the exercise of power ended on reasonable belief or reasons to believe.

precedents.case_name: Collector of Customs v. N. Sampathu Chetty
precedents.cited_proposition: powers based on reasonable belief or reasons to believe are subjective

anchor.surface_text: ...Collector of Customs v. N. Sampathu Chetty 1 , Babulal Amthalal v. Collector of Customs 2 , Pukhraj v. Kohli 3 and Nathmal Jalan v. Additional Collector of CUStOMS 4 which were all cases where the exercise of power ended on reasonable belief or reasons to believe.

precedents.case_name: Babulal Amthalal v. Collector of Customs
precedents.cited_proposition: powers based on reasonable belief are subjective

anchor.surface_text: ...Babulal Amthalal v. Collector of Customs 2 , Pukhraj v. Kohli 3 and Nathmal Jalan v. Additional Collector of CUStOMS 4 which were all cases where the exercise of power ended on reasonable belief or reasons to believe. But he held that the power under the proviso to s. 110 2 should be companystrued on the same princi- ples laid down in those decisions.

precedents.cited_proposition: powers based on reasonable belief are subjective

anchor.surface_text: ...Pukhraj v. Kohli 3 and Nathmal Jalan v. Additional Collector of CUStOMS 4 which were all cases where the exercise of power ended on reasonable belief or reasons to believe.

precedents.case_name: Nathmal Jalan v. Additional Collector of Customs
precedents.cited_proposition: powers based on reasonable belief are subjective

anchor.surface_text: The other decision, which takes a companytrary view, is of the High Court of Mysore in Ganeshmul Channilal Gandhi v. Col- lector of Central Excise . The grounds on which the learned Judges there took that view were i that the power was administrative, and 2 that if numberice were to be necessary, the authority which applies for extension would have to make a,disclosure about the investigation, which disclosure would be detrimental to the investigation itself.

precedents.case_name: Ganeshmul Channilal Gandhi v. Collector of Central Excise
precedents.cited_proposition: power under proviso is administrative, no notice required

anchor.surface_text: The unreported judgment of the High Court A.T.R. 19 8 Myscre F9. 8 14 of Bombay in M s. Prakash Cotton Mills Pvt. Ltd. v. Assistant Collector of Central Excise Bombay 1 does number throw any further light as it is mostly based on the reasoning of the Mysore High Court.

precedents.case_name: M/s. Prakash Cotton Mills Pvt. Ltd. v. Assistant Collector of Central Excise Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: power under proviso is administrative, no notice required (following Mysore HC)

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the first question must be answered In favour of the respondent, and therefore, the Division Bench was right in holding that the power under the proviso was quasijudicial, or at any rate, one requiring a judicial approach. Consequently, an opportunity of being heard ought to have been given to the respondent before orders for extension were made. The High Court,

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order upheld; restoration of seized watches ordered as extensions invalid without hearing
directions: restoration of the watches in question to the respondent

edges.explanation: Doctrine of audi alteram partem requiring hearing before quasi-judicial extension grounds the invalidity of ex parte orders
Sufficient cause requirement for judicial determination on facts grounds the argument empowering Collector to grant multiple extensions not exceeding six months at a time.
Sufficient cause concept requiring judicial determination on facts/materials addresses the considerations relevant for Collector granting extensions under the proviso.
First extension granted exemplifies Collector's power to grant extensions as needed for inquiry completion, supporting the argument on multiple extensions.
Grant of first four-month extension by Collector indicates sufficient cause was determined judicially as required by the sufficient cause concept.
Grant of first extension without mention of notice supports that proviso does not contemplate notice to respondent for extension considerations.
Second extension granted exemplifies Collector's power to grant extensions as needed for inquiry completion, supporting the argument on multiple extensions.
Grant of second two-month extension by Collector indicates sufficient cause was determined judicially as required by the sufficient cause concept.
Grant of second extension without mention of notice supports that proviso does not contemplate notice to respondent for extension considerations.
